question: Which one of the following statements regarding ‘Exit Poll’ is correct? (UPSC Prelims 1994)
option_1: ‘Exit Poll’ is a term used to denote a postelection survey of voters regarding the candidate in whose favour they had exercised their franchise.
option_2: ‘Exit Poll’ and ‘Opinion Poll’ are one and the same

option_4: ‘Exit Poll’ is an administrative device made recently by the Chief Election Commissioner to prevent impersonation.
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (A)

Exit polls :

  • These are the way to gather demographic information and other information about voters. For example, exit polls can provide information about why a voter voted for a particular candidate.
  • The ExitPoll automated system is a mobile system that gathers information from voters in real-time right after they leave a polling station.
  • The ExitPoll system works with information objects and their properties.

Opinion polls :

  • They are usually designed to represent the opinions of a population by conducting a series of questions and then extrapolating generalities in ratio or within confidence intervals. A person who conducts polls is referred to as a pollster.

question:
Consider the table given below providing some details of the results of the election to the Karnataka State Legislative Assembly held in December, 1994. (UPSC Prelims 1995)

 

Which one of the following electoral systems does the above election result reflect?
option_1: Hare system
option_2: Cumulative vote system
option_3: First past the post system
option_4: Plural vote system
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (C)

  • Elections to the Lok Sabha are carried out using a first-past-the-post electoral system. The country is split up into separate geographical areas known as constituencies, and the electors can cast one vote each for a candidate (although most candidatesstand as independents, most successful candidates stand as members of political parties), the winner being the candidate who gets the maximum votes.

Hare system :

  • It is a voting system that uses a ballot to rank candidates in order of preference. It’s also known as ranked choice voting, instant runoff voting (IRV), or single transferable vote (STV).

Cumulative voting :

  • It is a type of voting system that helps strengthen the ability of minority shareholders to elect a director. This method allows shareholders to cast all of their votes for a single nominee for the board of directors when the company has multiple openings on its board.

The First Past the Post System :

  • It is also known as the simple majority system or plurality system. In this voting system, the candidate with the most votes in a constituency is declared elected. Examples of FPTP in India include direct elections to the Lok Sabha and State Legislative Assemblies.
  • In the electoral race, the candidate who is ahead of others and crosses the winning post first is the winner.

Plural voting :

  • It is the practice whereby one person might be able to vote multiple times in an election. It is not to be confused with a plurality voting system which does not necessarily involve plural voting. Weighted voting is a generalisation of plural voting.

question:
Which of the following is/are extra- constitutional and extra legal device(s) for securing cooperation and coordination between the States in India? (UPSC Prelims 1995)

1.  The National Development Council

2. The Governors’ Conference

3. Zonal Councils

4. The Inter State Council

Choose the correct answer from the codes given below:
option_1: 1, 2 and 3
option_2: 1, 3 and 4
option_3: 3 and 4
option_4: 4 only
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (A) 

Constitutional body:

  • They are bodies which find considerable mention in the constitution, in ways like having a part of the constitution or an article explaining their position.

Extra Constitutional Body:

  • they are those bodies which do not find mention in the constitution. They are created by various methods which further explain their nomenclature.

Statutory Body:-

  • they are those bodies which are created by a law passed by the parliament which explicitly mentions the objectives for creation, their composition, Powers.
  • Such bodies are subject to change by a respective change in the law governing them. Other examples are - National Human Rights Commission, Lokpal, CBI, Zonal Council.

Executive bodies:-

  • they are those bodies which are created by an executive order i.e. order of a ministry of union or state. Such bodies have no constitutional or law backing them. One very infamous body was Planning commission (now replaced by NITI aayog).
  • Other such bodies are UIDAI (Aadhar card), which when faced controversy is undergoing shift to statutory body.

(1) The National Development Council (NDC) :

  • It was not provided for in the Constitution; it was set up by an executive order in 1952. It was meant to strengthen and mobilize the effort and resources of the nation in support of the Five-Year Plans and to promote cooperation between the Centre and the States.
  • Since it was created by an executive resolution (not a constitutional or statutory provision), it is called an extra-constitutional and extralegal body.

(2) The Governors’ Conference :

  • It is also an extra-constitutional and informal platform where the President and the Governors discuss national and administrative issues for better coordination between the Centre and the States.
  • It has no mention in the Constitution or in any law, and therefore it is also an extra-constitutional and extralegal device for cooperation.

(3) The Zonal Councils :

  • They were established under the provisions of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, which came into effect on 1st November 1956. They were created to promote cooperation and coordination among States and between the Centre and the States — especially after the reorganisation of states on a linguistic basis.
  • The Zonal Councils are not mentioned anywhere in the Constitution of India. They were not created under any Article of the Constitution, but rather by an Act of Parliament (a statute). Hence, they are called extra-constitutional bodies — meaning, they exist outside the framework of the Constitution.

(4) The Inter-State Council :

  • It is a constitutional body established under Article 263 of the Indian Constitution. Its purpose is to facilitate coordination between States and between the Centre and the States.
  • Hence, it is not extra-constitutional — it is explicitly provided for in the Constitution. Hence the correct answer is A.

question:
Article 156 of the Constitution of India provides that a Governor shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office. Which of the following can be deduced from this? (UPSC Prelims 1995)

1. No Governor can be removed from office till completion of his term.

2. No Governor can continue in office beyond a period of five years.

Select the correct answer from the codes given below:
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither1 nor 2
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (D) 

The correct answer is (D) Neither 1 nor 2.

  • According to Article 156(1), the Governor holds office during the pleasure of the President, meaning the President (in effect, the Union government) can remove a Governor at any time, even before the completion of five years. Therefore, the Governor can be removed earlier, and his term is not secure or fixed. Hence, the 1st statement is wrong.
  • Under Article 156(3), the Governor shall continue to hold office until his successor enters upon his office, even after the expiry of five years.
  • So, if a new Governor has not been appointed or has not assumed office, the current Governor continues to hold office beyond five years. Hence, the 2nd statement is wrong.

question: Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, etc. (Article 15 of the Constitution of India) is a Fundamental Right classifiable under............. (UPSC Prelims 1995)
option_1: the Right to Freedom of Religion
option_2: the Right against Exploitation
option_3: the Cultural and Educational Rights
option_4: the Right to Equality
solution_text:

  • Article 15 prohibits discrimination on the basis of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. The prohibition is against the state and not against any private individuals.
  • The clause is used to give horizontal reservations, such as reservations for visually impaired people. The Fundamental Rights are enshrined in Part III of the Constitution from Articles 12 to 35.

question: Agricultural income-tax is assigned to the State Governments by........... (UPSC Prelims 1995)
option_1: the Finance Commission
option_2: the National Development Council
option_3: the Inter-State Council
option_4: the Constitution of India
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (D) 

The Finance Commission (Article 280) :

  • It is a constitutional body that recommends the distribution of financial resources between the Centre and the States — such as the division of taxes and grants-in-aid. However, it does not assign taxes to either level of government.
  • It only recommends how proceeds of certain central taxes (like income tax, excise, etc.) should be shared. The power to assign or allocate taxes lies directly in the Constitution itself, particularly under the Seventh Schedule.

The National Development Council (NDC) :

  • It is an extra-constitutional body created in 1952 to promote cooperation between the Centre and States in planning matters.
  • Its main function was to discuss plans and policies for economic development, not to deal with tax assignment or revenue distribution. Therefore, the NDC has no role in assigning taxes such as agricultural income-tax.

The Inter-State Council :

  • It was established under Article 263 of the Constitution, aims to discuss, investigate, and recommend on issues of inter-State relations, coordination, and disputes. It is a deliberative and advisory body, not a fiscal or revenue-distributing body.
  • The Constitution itself makes clear provisions regarding taxation powers between the Union and the States.

Under the Seventh Schedule, The State List (List II) includes Entry 46:

  •  “Taxes on agricultural income.” Thus, agricultural income-tax is a State subject, and the power to levy, collect, and retain this tax is assigned directly to the States by the Constitution. This means States like Tamil Nadu, Kerala, and Assam have their own Agricultural Income Tax Acts.
  • Hence, agricultural income tax is assigned to the States not by any institution or body, but by constitutional division of powers.

question: In which one of the following States of India it is legal for a Hindu male and illegal for a Muslim male to have more than one living wife? (UPSC Prelims 1995)

question: Which one of the following is incorrect in respect of Local Government in India? (UPSC Prelims 1995)

question: Which one of the following is not explicitly stated in the Constitution of India but followed as a convention? (UPSC Prelims 1995)
option_1: The Finance Minister is to be a Member of the Lower House
option_2: The Prime Minister has to resign if he loses majority in the Lower House
option_3: All the parts of India are to be represented in the Council of Ministers
option_4: In the event of both the President and the Vice President demitting office simultaneously before the end of their tenure the Speaker of the Lower House of the Parliament will officiate as the President
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (B)

  • The Constitution of India has certain conventions that are not explicitly stated but are followed as a matter of tradition. One such convention is that the Prime Minister must resign if they lose the majority in the Lower House of Parliament.

Here are some other conventions that are not explicitly stated in the Constitution of India:

1. The leader of the political party that secures an absolute majority in the Lok Sabha will be appointed as the Prime Minister.

2. The Council of Ministers must represent all parts of India.

3. If both the President and the Vice President leave office simultaneously before the end of their term, the Speaker of the lower House of Parliament will serve as the President.

  • The conventions of the constitution are unwritten principles that are rules, even though they can’t be enforced by law in the courts.

question: Which of the following are the States in which the Lokayukta Act includes the Chief Minister in its ambit? (UPSC Prelims 1995)
option_1: West Bengal and Kerala
option_2: Gujarat and Maharashtra
option_3: Madhya Pradesh and Orissa
option_4: Rajasthan and Karnataka
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (D)

The Chief Minister is included in the jurisdiction of the Lokayukta in the following states:

  •  Himachal Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat, Rajasthan, Karnataka.

The Chief Minister is not included in the jurisdiction of the Lokayukta in the following states:

  •  Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Orissa.

The Lokpal and Lokayukta Act of 2013 :

  • It established the Lokpal and Lokayukta institutions to investigate corruption allegations against public officials. The Lokpal investigates corruption at the national level, while the Lokayukta performs the same function at the state level.
  • The Act requires each state to appoint a Lokayukta, similar to the Lokpal, to investigate corruption complaints against government officers. The institution should have both judicial and non-judicial members.
  • The Lokayukta has a fixed tenure and must perform its functions independently and impartially. In most states, the Lokayukta’s term of office is five years or 65 years of age, whichever is earlier. The Lokayukta can initiate an investigation against the Chief Minister with the Assembly’s prior approval.
  • The Act’s objective is to check corruption in India. It provides an effective way to counter corruption at all levels of government and brings transparency and accountability to the system.
  • In 2022, Maharashtra became the first state to pass the Lokayukta Bill, which brings the Chief Minister and council of ministers under the ambit of the anti-corruption ombudsman.
  • The Bill gives additional powers to the Lokayukta to direct state agencies to probe public servants, including the Chief Minister and state ministers.

question: The power of the Supreme Court of India to decide disputes between the Centre and the States falls under its........ (UPSC Prelims 1996)
option_1: advisory jurisdiction
option_2: appellate jurisdiction
option_3: original jurisdiction
option_4: constitutional jurisdiction
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (C)

  • The Supreme Court of India’s power to decide disputes between the Centre and the States is covered under its “original jurisdiction”. This is according to Article 131 of the Constitution of India.

The Supreme Court has six types of jurisdiction:

1. Original 

2. Appellate 

3. Advisory 

4. Review 

5. Inherent 

6. Extraordinary.

1. “Original jurisdiction” ;

  •  It refers to the power of a court to hear a case first, before any other court. It means the power to hear and determinea dispute in the first instance.
  •  The Supreme Court (SC) has original jurisdiction to decide disputes arising between different units of the Indian Federation.

This includes:

1. Centre and one or more states

2. Centre and any state(s) on one side and one or more states on the other

3. Two or more states

  • The Supreme Court of India is the final authority to ensure that the division of powers as specified in the constitution is obeyed by both the Union and the State governments.

2. Advisory Jurisdiction :

  • The Supreme Court’s advisory jurisdiction is when a constitutional body or lower court seeks advice from a higher court on a legal matter.
  • Article 143 of the Indian Constitution gives the Supreme Court advisory jurisdiction. This allows the President to ask for the Supreme Court’s opinion on any issue of law or matter of public importance.
  • For example, the President can ask the Court’s opinion on treaties and agreements made before the Constitution was framed. The views taken by the Court are not binding on the President and it is not law within Article 141.

3. Appellate Jurisdiction :

  • The Supreme Court of India has a broad appellate jurisdiction over all courts and tribunals in the country. This means that the Supreme Court can review appeals from lower courts and change or review the decisions made by those court.

4. Inherent jurisdiction :

  • It is a legal term that refers to a court’s power to make decisions when there is no specific law or statute that addresses the issue. It’s a broad doctrine that allows a court to control its own processes and procedures.

5. Review Jurisdiction :

  • According to Article 137 of the Constitution of India, the Supreme Court has the power to review any of its judgments or orders. The Supreme Court’s review powers enable it to modify a judgment suffering from mistakes.
  • Parties who are dissatisfied by the outcome of a Supreme Court judgment, can seek a review of it under Article 137 of the Constitution. A review petition must be filed within 30 days of pronouncement of the judgement.

6. Extraordinary jurisdiction :

  • It is a power that allows the Supreme Court of India to grant special leave to appeal from any judgment, decree, determination, sentence, or order passed by any court or tribunal in the territory of India. This power is not limited to any particular subject matter or court.

question: According to the Constitution of India, the term ‘district judge’ shall not include............ (UPSC Prelims 1996)
option_1: chief presidency magistrate
option_2: sessions judge
option_3: tribunal judge
option_4: chief judge of a small cause court
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (C)

  • According to the Constitution of India, the term “district judge” does not include a tribunal judge. Tribunal judges oversee specific areas of law and handle specialized or technical matters. Their activities are not confined to a specific geographical jurisdiction like a district.
  • According to the Constitution of India, a person to be eligible for appointment as a District Judge should be an advocates or a pleader of seven years’ standing or more.

Tribunals in India :

  • They are quasi-judicial bodies that resolve disputes related to administration, taxation, environment, and securities. They are adjudicatory bodies that serve as an alternative to the traditional court system.
  • Tribunals are established by law and are intended to provide a faster adjudication platform than traditional courts. They also provide expertise on certain subject matters.

Some examples of tribunals in India include:

1. Central Administrative Tribunal (CAT)

2. Income Tax Appellate Tribunal (ITAT)

3. Customs, Excise and Service

4. Tax Appellate Tribunal (CESTAT)

5. National Green Tribunal (NGT)

6. Competition Appellate Tribunal

7. Debts Recovery Tribunal

Tribunals have certain powers, including:

1. Discovery and production of documents

2. Reception of evidence on affidavits

3. Requisitioning of public records from any court or office

4. Issuing of any commission for the examination of witnesses.

  • The Tribunal Reforms Bill, 2021 was passed in both Houses of the Parliament in August 2021. The bill replaced the ordinance which had been introduced in February 2021.

Sessions judge :

  • He is a judge who presides over a sessions court. The sessions court is the most powerful court in a district for criminal cases.
  • The district and sessions judge is often referred to as “district judge” when presiding over civil matters and “sessions judge” when presiding over criminal matters. The district and sessions judge works directly under the control of the governor of the state.
  • The CrPC enables sessions judges to pass any sentence authorized by law. The high court may appoint a sessions judge of one sessions division to also be an additional sessions judge of another division.

question: When the Chief Justice of a High Court acts in an administrative capacity, he is subject to........... (UPSC Prelims 1996)
option_1: the writ jurisdiction of any of the other judges of the High Court
option_2: special control exercised by the Chief Justice of India
option_3: discretionary powers of the Governor of the state
option_4: special powers provided to the Chief Minister in this regard
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (A)

  • When the chief justice of a High Court acts in an administrative capacity, he is subject to. The writ jurisdiction of any of the other judges of the High Court.

Writ jurisdiction :

  • It is the power of a body with judicial or administrative jurisdiction to issue formal written orders.
  • In India, the Supreme Court’s writ jurisdiction is set out in Article 32 of the Constitution. The Supreme Court has the power to issue writs to enforce fundamental rights.

The types of writs that the Supreme Court can issue are:

  • Habeas corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Quo warranto, Certiorari. The Supreme Court acts as a custodian of the fundamental rights of citizens. It is considered the “guarantor” and “defender” of the fundamental rights of the citizens of India.
  • The writ jurisdiction of High Courts is wider than the writ jurisdiction of the Supreme Court. High Courts can issue writs for the enforcement of fundamental rights or for any other purposes.
  • In 1997, the Supreme Court ruled that the writ jurisdiction of both the high court and the Supreme Court constitute a part of the basic structure of the Constitution.

question:
Consider the following statements: No one can be compelled to sing the National Anthem since........... (UPSC Prelims 1996)

1. It will be violative of the Right to freedom of speech and expression.

2. It will be violative of the Right to freedom of conscience and practise and propagation of religion.

3. There is no legal provision obliging any one to sing the National Anthem.

Of these statements
option_1: 1 and 2 are correct
option_2: 2 and 3 are correct
option_3: 1, 2 and 3 are correct
option_4: None is correct
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (C) 

  • Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution guarantees the freedom of speech and expression. The right includes the freedom not to speak or express oneself.
  • Forcing someone to sing would be a violation of this freedom. The Court observed that remaining silent during the anthem as a matter of conscience is also a form of expression protected by Article 19(1)(a).
  • Article 25 protects the freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion.
  • In the Bijoe Emmanuel case, the Court recognised that the students’ refusal to sing was based on sincere religious belief, not disrespect. Therefore, compelling them to sing would violate their freedom of conscience and religion.
  • There is no law in India—including the Prevention of Insults to National Honour Act, 1971—that makes it mandatory for anyone to sing the National Anthem. The law only prohibits intentional disrespect (such as insulting gestures or acts) during its playing or singing.
  • Thus, standing respectfully without singing is fully lawful and acceptable. All three statements (1, 2, and 3) are correct.

question:

question: In which of the following countries will the no confidence motion to bring down the government passed by the legislature be valid only when the legislature is able to find simultaneously a majority to elect a successor government? (UPSC Prelims 1997)
option_1: France
option_2: Germany
option_3: Italy
option_4: Portugal

The correct answer is (b) Germany.

  • Germany has a unique system where the no-confidence motion to bring down the government passed by the legislature will be valid only when the legislature is able to find simultaneously a majority to elect successor government. This system is known as the constructive vote of no-confidence.
  • Under this system, a vote of no-confidence can only be successful if the legislature can agree on an alternative candidate for chancellor.
  • This means that a new government must be formed and presented to the President at the same time that the old government is being removed. This system was put inplace to prevent political instability and ensure that the government can continue to function effectively.

question: Proportional representation is NOT necessary in a country where............ (UPSC Prelims 1997)

question: Which one of the following was NOT proposed by the 73rd Constitutional Amendment in the area of Panchayati Raj?(UPSC Prelims 1997)
option_1: Thirty per cent seats in all elected rural local bodies will be reserved for women candidates at all levels
option_2: The States will constitute their Finance Commissions to allocate resources to Panchayati Raj Institutions
option_3: The Panchayati Raj elected functionaries will be disqualified to hold their offices if they have more than two children
option_4: The elections will be held in six months time if Panchayati Raj bodies are superceded or dissolved by the State government

question: The concept of Public Interest Litigation originated in........... (UPSC Prelims 1997)

Public Interest Litigation (PIL) :

  • It is a legal action filed in the Indian courts to protect the public’s rights and promote the general welfare. The concept of PIL originated from the power of judicial review.
  • To file a PIL, the petitioner must be acting in good faith and have a legitimate stake in the outcome of the case. The court may also exercise suo moto cognizance. The concept of “Locus Standi” has been relaxed in the case of PILs.
  • This allows the court to look into grievances filed on behalf of those who are poor, illiterate, deprived, or disabled and are unable to approach the courts themselves.

There are two types of PIL:

1. Representative Social Action

2. Citizen Social Action Justice Bhagwati, who was Chief Justice of India from 1985 to 1986, is known as the father of PIL in India.

Some examples of successful PIL cases include:

1. Bonded labor

2. Neglected children

3. Exploitation of temporary workers

4. Brutal acts against women

5. Environmental pollution

6. Food adulteration

7. Preservation of culture and legacy

  • The Supreme Court of India has the discretionary authority to issue any decrees or orders that may be required to provide full justice.

question:
Assertion (A) : Willful disobedience or noncompliance of Court Orders and use of derogatory language about judicial behaviour amounts to Contempt of Court. 

Reason (R) : Judicial activism cannot be practised without arming the judiciary with punitive powers to punish contemptuous behaviour.

In the context of the above two statements, which one of the following is correct? (UPSC Prelims 1997)
option_1: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
option_2: Both A and Rare true, but R is not a correct explanation of A
option_3: A is true, but R is false
option_4: A is false, but R is true
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (B)

  • Contempt of court is a crime that involves disrespecting or disobeying a court of law and its officers. It can also include conduct that interferes with the orderly administration of justice.

Examples of contempt of court include:

1. Disrupting court proceedings

2. Interfering with attempts to obtain evidence

3. Destroying evidence

4. Disobeying a court order

5. Intimidating witnesses

6. Being impolite to legal authorities in the courtroom

7. Rebelliously failing to follow a court order

  • In India, the Parliament has the power to make laws on contempt of court. The Contempt of Courts Act, 1971 defines contempt of court as civil contempt or criminal contempt.

Civil contempt of court :

  • It occurs when someone fails to comply with a court order, which can harm the justice system or a private individual or party.
  • Civil contempt of court carries quasi-criminal penalties, rather than direct criminal penalties. Criminal contempt of court is behavior that disrespects, offends, or disobeys the authority of a court. It can occur directly or indirectly, in the presence of the court or outside of it.

Here are some examples of criminal contempt of court:

1. Insulting the judge

2. Creating a disturbance at trial

3. Disrupting court proceedings

4. Interfering with attempts to obtain evidence

Criminal contempt can also include any act or publication that:

1. Scandalizes the court

2. Prejudices any judicial proceeding

3. Interferes with the administration of justice in any other manner

Judicial activism :

  • It is a legal term that describes when judges make rulings based on their personal or political views, rather than on current legislation.
  • It can also refer to when judges let their personal feelings influence a conviction or sentence. Judicial activism is a controversial topic.
  • Some opponents say it overrides the federal government’s checks and balances. The phrase “judicial activism” may have been coined by American historian Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr. in a 1947 article.

question: Which one of the following Schedules of the Constitution of India contains provisions regarding Anti-Defection Act? (UPSC Prelims 1998)
option_1: Second Schedule
option_2: Fifth Schedule
option_3: Eighth Schedule
option_4: Tenth Schedule
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (D)

1. The Tenth Schedule of the Constitution of India :

  • It is also known as the Anti-Defection Law, contains provisions regarding anti defection. The 52nd Constitutional Amendment Act of 1985 added the Tenth Schedule to the Constitution.
  • The Anti-Defection Law aims to prevent political defections, which can undermine the principles of Indian democracy. The law disqualifies legislators who violate the will of their political party.
  • It also aims to strengthen democracy by making parliamentarians more loyal to the political parties they were aligned with when elected.

The Anti-Defection Law disqualifies elected members who:

1. Voluntarily join a party other than their own

2. Vote against any direction issued by their political party, unless they have prior permission from the party

  • The Speaker or Chairman of the respective Legislative house decides on disqualification arising out of defection.

2. The Second Schedule of the Indian Constitution :

It covers the allowances, privileges, and emoluments of the following:

1. The President of India

2. The Governors of Indian States

3. The Speaker of Lok Sabha and Deputy Speaker of Lok Sabha

4. The Chairman of Rajya Sabha and Deputy Chairman of Rajya Sabha

5. The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of Legislative Assemblies of Indian States

  •  The Second Schedule also includes provisions for the President, Vice President, Council of Ministers, and more.

3. The Fifth Schedule of the Indian Constitution :

  • It deals with the management and administration of Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes where tribal communities are in a majority. The Fifth Schedule aims to hold the state accountable for the advancement of tribals’ educational and economic objectives.

The Fifth Schedule protects tribal interests in the states of:

  • Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Gujarat, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Himachal Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Odisha, Rajasthan.
  • The Fifth Schedule does not apply to the states of Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram.
  • Tribal advisory councils (TACs) are constitutional bodies formed under the Fifth Schedule to deal with welfare and advancement of scheduled tribes in states.

4. The Sixth Schedule of the Indian Constitution :

  • It is a special provision that allows for the administration of tribal areas in Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram. xThe Sixth Schedule was enacted in 1949 to protect indigenous and tribal groups.
  • The Sixth Schedule allows for the creationof autonomous District Councils (ADCs) in certain tribal areas. These ADCs have the power to make laws on a range of subjects, including land allotment, water course use, and property inheritance.
  • The administrative powers and functions of these District Councils and Regional Councils vary from state to state. Most of these autonomous district councils are located in North East India, with the exception of two in Ladakh and one in West Bengal.

5. The Eighth Schedule of the Constitution of India :

  • It lists the official languages of the Republic of India. The Eighth Schedule originally included 14 languages, but the 71st Amendment in 1992 added three more languages, and the 92nd Amendment in 2003 added four more languages.

The 22 languages included in the Eighth Schedule are:

  • Assamese, Bengali, Gujarati, Hindi, Kannada, Kashmiri, Konkani, Malayalam, Manipuri, Marathi, Nepali, Oriya, Punjabi, Sanskrit, Sindhi, Tamil, Telugu, Urdu, Bodo, Santhali, Maithili, Dogri.

The Eighth Schedule also includes constitutional provisions relating to other languages, including:

  • Angika, Banjara, Bazika, Bhojpuri, Bhoti, Bhotia, Bundelkhandi, Chhattisgarhi, Dhatki.

question: Panchayati Raj was first introduced in India in October, 1959 in............. (UPSC Prelims 1998)
option_1: Rajasthan
option_2: Tamil Nadu
option_3: Kerala
option_4: Karnataka

  • Panchayati Raj was first introduced in India on October 2, 1959 in the Nagaur district of Rajasthan. The late Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru inaugurated the scheme.
  • Rajasthan adopted the three-tier system, while Tamil Nadu adopted the two-tier system. Andhra Pradesh also adopted the system in 1959.
  • The Rajasthan Panchayat Act was enacted in 1953. The goal was to decentralize powers and have a three-tier structure of local self-governing bodies at the district, block, and village levels.

question: The Indian parliamentary system is different from the British parliamentary system in that India has........... (UPSC Prelims 1998)
option_1: both a real and a nominal executive
option_2: a system of collective responsibility
option_3: bicameral legislature
option_4: the system of judicial review
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (D)

  • The parliamentary system of government in India is largely based on the British parliamentary system. However, it never became a replica of the British system and differs in some respects.
  • The British system is based on the doctrine of the sovereignty of Parliament, while the Parliament is not supreme in India and enjoys limited and restricted powers due to a written Constitution, federal system, judicial review and fundamental rights.

Judicial review :

  • It is the power of the judiciary to examine and invalidate laws and actions that conflict with the Constitution of India.
  • The Supreme Court and High Courts of India have the power to examine the constitutionality of any law or action. If the court finds that a law or action is inconsistent with the Constitution, it can declare it unconstitutional and inapplicable.
  • The concept of judicial review originated in the United States and was adapted for India. It was first established in India in the 1951 case of Shankari Prasad v. Union of India.
  • The judiciary is one of three organs of government in India, along with the legislature and the executive. The legislature makes laws, the executive implements them, and the judiciary ensures that the laws are not in conflict with the Constitution.

Bicameral legislature :

  • It is a law-making body with two separate assemblies, chambers, or houses. The two assemblies must agree when new laws are made.
  • Bicameral legislatures are more common in federal, large, and presidential states.

Some examples of countries with bicameral legislatures include:

  • The United States, Australia, Brazil, Canada, Germany, India.

question: In the new Panchayati Raj Bill enacted in 1993, there are several fresh provisions deviating from the past. Which one of the following is not one such provision? (UPSC Prelims 1999)
option_1: A number of added responsibilities in the area of agriculture, rural development, primary education and social forestry among others.
option_2: Elections being made mandatory for all posts at the time they are due
option_3: A statutory representation for women in the panchayats, upto a third of the strength.
option_4: Regular remuneration to the panchayat members, so as to ensure their punctuality such powers and accountability.

  • The Panchayati Raj Institutions (PRIs) were given constitutional status in 1992 by the Seventy-Third Constitutional Amendment Act.
  • The act established a three-tier system for PRIs, with elections, reservation of seats for women, Scheduled Castes, and Scheduled Tribes, and devolution of funds and functions.

The act’s main features include:

1. A three-tier system of Panchayati Raj for states with a population of over 20 lakh Panchayat elections every five years

2. Reservation of seats for women, Scheduled Castes, and Scheduled Tribes (not less than one-third of seats)

3. Appointment of a State Finance Commission

  • The act also states that every panchayat shall continue for five years. If dissolved before its expiry, a new panchayat must be elected within six months.
  • The governor of a state shall constitute a finance commission to decide how revenue from taxes and duties should be distributed between the states and panchayats.

question: The Constitution of India recognises............. (UPSC Prelims 1999)

option_3: religious and linguistic minorities

question:
Consider the following statements about the recent amendments to the Election Law by the Representation of the People (Amendment) Act, 1996.............. (UPSC Prelims 1999)

(1) Any conviction for the offence of insulting the Indian National flag or the Constitution of India shall entail disqualification for contesting elections to Parliament and State Legislatures for six years from the date of conviction.

(2) There is an increase in the security deposit which a candidate has to make to contest the election to the Lok Sabha.

(3) A candidate cannot now stand for election from more than one Parliamentary constituency.

(4) No election will now be countermanded on the death of a contesting candidate.

Which of the above statements are correct?
option_1: 2 and 3
option_2: 1, 2 and 4
option_3: 1 and 3
option_4: 1, 2, 3 and 4
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (B) 

  • The Representation of the People (Amendment) Act, 1996 introduced a new provision stating that anyone convicted under the Prevention of Insults to National Honour Act, 1971 (which penalizes insult to the national flag or Constitution) will be disqualified for six years from the date of conviction from contesting elections to Parliament or State Legislatures. This amendment was meant to uphold the dignity of national symbols. Thus, statement 1 is correct.
  • The 1996 Amendment Act increased the security deposit amounts for contesting elections to both the Lok Sabha and State Legislative Assemblies. This was done to discourage non-serious candidates from filing nominations.
  • For example, the Lok Sabha deposit was raised from 500 to 10,000 for general candidates, and from 250 to 5,000 for Scheduled Castes/Scheduled Tribes candidates. Thus, statement 2 is correct.
  • This statement is wrong because the 1996 amendment did not prohibit multiple constituency contests. A candidate was still allowed to contest from a maximum of two constituencies (as per Section 33(7) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951).

  • Before the 1996 amendment, if a candidate died after nominations were finalized, the election was countermanded (cancelled) and re-conducted later.

question:
Consider the following statements: An amendment of the Constitution of India can be initiated by the............ (UPSC Prelims 1999)

option_4: 1 and 2
solution_text:

  • A minister or private member can initiate an amendment to the Constitution of India by introducing a bill in either House of Parliament. This can be done in the Lok Sabha or the Rajya Sabha, but not in the state legislatures.
  • The bill must then pass in each House by a majority of the total membership and a majority of at least two-thirds of the members present and voting. If the amendment seeks to change the Constitution’s federal character, it must also be ratified by the legislature of all the states of India.

question:
Consider the following statements regarding the National Human Rights Commission of India............ (UPSC Prelims 1999)

(1) Its Chairman must be a retired Chief Justice of India.

(2) It has formations in each state as State Human Rights Commission.

(3) Its powers are only recommendatory in nature.

(4) It is mandatory to appoint a woman as a member of the Commission.

option_2: 2 and 4
option_3: 2 and 3
option_4: 1 and 3
solution_text:

The National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) :

  • It is a statutory body of the Government of India that was established in 1993. The NHRC’s mission is to protect and promote human rights. The NHRC is responsible for the protection and promotion of human rights, which are defined as “Rights Relating To Life, liberty, equality and dignity of the individual”.
  • These rights are guaranteed by the constitution or embodied in the international covenants and enforceable by courts in India. The NHRC is located at New Delhi.
  • The Commission consists of a Chairperson, five full-time Members, and seven deemed Members. The chairman and members hold office for a term of three years or until they attain the age of 70 years, whichever is earlier.
  • The NHRC is in conformity with the Paris Principles, adopted at the first international workshop on national institutions for the promotion and protection of human rights held in Paris in October 1991.
  • Arun Kumar Mishra is the chairperson of the National Human Rights Commission of India. The chairperson of the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) must be a former or current judge of the Supreme Court of India. The NHRC also includes one member who is or has been a Supreme Court judge, and one member who is or has been a High Court Chief Justice.
  • The president can remove the chairperson or any member of the NHRC from office if they are found to be incapable or have misbehaved. As of December 2018, 26 states have set up State Human Rights Commissions (SHRCs). The NHRC has requested all states, including Uttaranchal and Jharkhand, to set up SHRCs.

The following states have not constituted SHRCs:

  • Arunachal Pradesh, Goa, Haryana, Meghalaya, Mizoram, Nagaland, Tripura, Uttarakhand. The National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) has recommendatory powers. The NHRC’s decisions are only recommendatory, and governments are not required to implement them.
  • The Protection of Human Rights Act, 1993, specifies that it is mandatory that at least one member of the NHRC should be a woman. This provision ensures that there is gender diversity in the commission and that women’s human rights issues are adequately represented.

question: British citizen staying in India cannot claim Right to.............. (UPSC Prelims 1999)

1. Fundamental rights available only to the citizens are:

  • The act is about prohibiting discrimination and equality of opportunity for citizens. It prohibits discrimination against Indians based on religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. It makes it mandatory to treat all Indians equally.

question: The Speaker can ask a member of the House to stop speaking and let another member speak. This phenomenon is known as.............. (UPSC Prelims 2000)
option_1: decorum
option_2: crossing the floor
option_3: interpellation
option_4: yielding the floor
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (D)

  • Yielding the floor is when the Speaker of the House asks a member to stop speaking and allows another member to speak.
  • In some legislative bodies, this practice is allowed, but it is not allowed in deliberative assemblies unless specifically authorized in the rules.

Decorum in parliament :

  • It refers to the rules and traditions that ensure debate proceeds in a civil and orderly manner. The Speaker is responsible for maintaining the dignity and decorum of the House.
  • However, members themselves must also take responsibility for their behavior and conduct their business in an appropriate fashion.

Some examples of decorum in parliament include:

1. Members should enter and leave the Chamber with decorum and in such a manner as not to disturb the proceedings of the House.

2. Members should bow to the Chair while entering or leaving the House and also before taking or leaving their seats.

3. MPs must not use unparliamentary language.

4. MPs may not read their speeches.

5. A Member must be in his or her place to take part in any proceedings in the House and address his or her remarks to the Chair.

6. A Member, Delegate, or Resident Commissioner who desires to speak or deliver a matter to the House shall rise and respectfully address the Speaker.

7. “Crossing the floor”—Passing between the member addressing the House and the Chair is considered a breach of Parliamentary etiquette.

Crossing the floor :

  • It refers to when a member of parliament refuses to vote with their own party and instead votes with the opposing side. This can happen when a question is being decided in parliament and a vote is taken. Parliamentary parties usually vote as a team, with all members voting the same way.

Interpellation :

  • It is a formal request from a parliament to its government. It’s a process where questions are formally asked of a government minister in parliament.
  • Interpellation is different from question time because it often involves a separate procedure. It can also be known as question hour.

question: “....instil into the vast millions of workers, men and women, who actually do the job, a sense of partnership and of cooperative performance..” The above passage relates to.............. (UPSC Prelims 2000)

question:

question: The 73rd Constitution Amendment Act, 1992 refers to the........... (UPSC Prelims 2000)
option_1: Generation of gainful employment for the unemployed and the underemployed men and women in rural area
option_2: Generation of employment for the able bodied adults who are in need and desirous of work during the lean agricultural season
option_3: Laying the foundation for strong and vibrant Panchayati Raj Institutions in the country
option_4: Guarantee of right to life, liberty and security of person, equality before law and equal protection without discrimination
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (C)

  • The 73rd Constitution Amendment Act of 1992 relates to Panchayati Raj. It re-introduced panchayats as local self governance institutions, with a three-tiered structure for operations at the village, group of villages, and district levels.

The 73rd Amendment Act includes the following provisions:

1. Reservation of seats for women, Scheduled Castes, and Scheduled Tribes in Panchayats

2. Three-tier system

3. Reservation of SC/ST/OBCs

4. Direct elections

5. Minimum age qualification for election to PRIs of 21 years

6. Indirect election of intermediate and district level chairmen

7. Tenure of five years

8. State Finance Commission (SFC) to be appointed every five years for review

  • The 73rd Amendment Act also prohibits judges from interfering with local elections. It also bars courts from challenging laws about the delineation of constituencies and allotment of seats. The 73rd Amendment Act brought the Panchayati Raj System to rural India.

The 74th Constitutional Amendment Act (74th CAA) of 1992 came into effect on June 1, 1993 :

  • It is also known as the Nagarpalika Act. The 74th CAA provides a framework for decentralizing powers and authorities to municipal bodies at different levels.
  • It also introduced the concept of local self government and municipality in India. The 74th CAA provides constitutional status to Urban Local Bodies (ULBs).

It also established two new tiers of government at the local level:

1. the Panchayat Raj and

2. the Nagar Palika.

Some provisions of the 74th CAA include:

1. Seats for SC and ST are reserved in proportion to their population.

2. Women are allocated 1/3 of the total number of seats.

  • The state legislature has the authority to adopt any provision for backward-class reservation in municipalities at any level.

question:
Consider the following statements about the minorities in India............ (UPSC Prelims 2001)

1. The Government of India has notified five communities, namely, Muslims, Sikhs, Christians, Buddhists and Zoroastrians as Minorities.

2. The National Commission for Minorities was given statutory status in 1993.

option_2: 1 and 4
option_3: 2, 3, and 4
option_4: 1, 2, 3 and 4
solution_text: EXPLANATION : (D) The Indian Constitution does not define the term “minority”. However, it does outline the rights of minorities, which are based on religion or language. The National Commission for Minorities (NCM) is a statutory body established by the Indian parliament in 1992. The NCM was established on May 17, 1993, and the first statutory commission was set up on that day. The National Commission for Minorities Act of 1992 identifies the following communities as minorities: Muslims, Sikhs, Christians, Buddhists, Jains, Zoroastrians (Parsis). The Constitution of India recognizes and protects religious and linguistic minorities. Article 29 of the Constitution protects the interests of minority groups. It also gives linguistic minorities the right to establish their own educational institutions. Article 30 of the Constitution gives religious and linguistic minorities the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice. It also protects minority-managed educational institutions from discrimination in receiving aid from the state. An ethnic, religious, or linguistic minority is any group of people who make up less than half of a state’s population. The members of these groups share common characteristics of culture, religion, or language.

question: In what way does the Indian Parliament exercise control over the administration? (UPSC Prelims 2001)

Periodic reports: The Parliament requires administrators to submit periodic reports. Consultative Committees: The Parliament uses Consultative Committees of different ministries to exercise control. Questions: Members of Parliament (MPs) hold the executive accountable by asking questions and supplementary questions. question: If a new State of the Indian Union is to be created, which one of the following Schedules of the Constitution must be amended? (UPSC Prelims 2001)
option_1: First
option_2: Second

T he First Schedule lists the names, territories, and capitals of India’s existing states and union territories. It also includes any changes to their borders and the laws used to make those changes. To amend the First Schedule, a special majority is required in both houses of Parliament. This means that the amendment must be supported by a majority of the total membership of each house and by a majority of not less than two-thirds of the members present and voting. 1. T he Second Schedule of the Indian Constitution covers the salaries, allowances, and additional grants for the following officials:President of IndiaGovernors of Indian States Speaker and Deputy Speaker of Lok Sabha Chairman and Deputy Chairman of Rajya Sabha Speaker and Deputy Speaker of Legislative Assemblies of Indian States T he Second Schedule also lists the emoluments for holders of constitutional offices, such as the salaries of the President, Vice President, Ministers, Judges, and Comptroller and Auditor-General of India.T he third schedule of the Indian Constitution contains the forms of oath and affirmation for: 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. 6. 7. 8. 9. The Fifth Schedule of the Indian Constitution : It deals with the management and administration of Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes where tribal communities are in a majority. The Fifth Schedule protects tribal interests in the states of: Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Gujarat, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Himachal Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Odisha, Rajasthan. The Sixth Schedule of the Indian Constitution : It is a special provision that allows for the administration of tribal areas in Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram. The administrative powers and functions of these District Councils and Regional Councils vary from state to state. Most of these autonomous district councils are located in North East India, with the exception of two in Ladakh and one in West Bengal.

question: Which one of the following duties is NOT performed by the Comptroller and Auditor General of India? (UPSC Prelims 2001)
option_1: To audit and report on all expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of India
option_2: To audit and report on all expenditure from the Contingency Funds and Public Accounts
option_3: To audit and report on all trading. manufacturing, profit and loss accounts
option_4: To control the receipt and issue of public money, and to ensure that the public revenue is lodged in the exchequer
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (D) 

The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) of India is an independent constitutional authority established under Article 148 to 151 of the Constitution. The CAG acts as the guardian of the public purse and ensures accountability of the executive to the legislature in matters of public finance. His main function is to audit the accounts of the Union and the States and report to the President or Governors, who then place these reports before the . The CAG audits and reports on all expenditures from the Consolidated Fund of India, which includes all revenues received by the Government of India, loans raised, and money received in repayment of loans. This is explicitly mentioned in Article 149 of the Constitution and the CAG’s (Duties, Powers and Conditions of Service) Act, 1971. In addition to the Consolidated Fund, the CAG also audits the Contingency Fund of India (used for urgent, unforeseen expenditures) and the Public Account of India (which holds funds such as provident funds, judicial deposits, etc.). Thus, this is also a function legally assigned to the CAG. The CAG is empowered to audit the accounts of government departments engaged in commercial or manufacturing activities, such as government companies or corporations. He prepares and submits reports on their trading, manufacturing, profit, and loss accounts to ensure transparency and accountability. To control the receipt and issue of public money, and to ensure that the public revenue is lodged in the exchequer — This function belongs to the executive branch (mainly the Finance Ministry and Treasury officers), not to the CAG. The CAG’s role is not to control financial transactions in real time but to audit them after they occur — i.e., he performs a post-facto audit. Therefore, while the CAG ensures that funds are used properly and in accordance with law, he does not control or supervise the day-to-day receipt and expenditure of government money. Thus, the correct answer is D.

question: Which one of the following rights was described by Dr BR Ambedkar as the heartand soul of the Constitution? (UPSC Prelims 2002)

  • It is the right to choose a religion and worship without interference. It also includes the freedom to change one’s religion or beliefs. The right to freedom of religion is described in Articles 25, 26, 27, and 28 of the Indian constitution.

  • It is a fundamental right in India that ensures that the government does not deny any person equality before the law or equal protection of the laws. This means that the laws apply equally to all, regardless of a person’s status.

question: Which one of the following authorities recommends the principles governing the grants in-aid of the revenues to the states out of the Consolidated Fund of India? (UPSC Prelims 2002)

option_2: Inter-State Council
option_3: Union Ministry of Finance
option_4: Public Accounts Committee
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (A)

  • The Finance Commission recommends the principles governing the grants-in aid of the revenues to the states out of the Consolidated Fund of India. The President of India constitutes the Finance Commission every five years or earlier if necessary.

The Commission’s duties include:

1. Recommending the distribution of tax revenues between the Union and the States

2. Recommending the principles governing the grants-in-aid of the revenues of the States

3. Recommending measures to increase the resources of the State

  • A grant-in-aid is money from a central or state government for a specific project. The government and legislature usually decide that the recipient should be publicly funded but operate independently from the state.

The Inter-State Council :

  • It is a body that promotes collaboration and cooperation between central and inter-state activities. It was established in 1990 under Article 263 of the Constitution of India.

The council’s role is to:

1. Investigate and discuss issues of common interest between the Union and states, or among states

2. Identify and investigate possible problems between states

3. Share solutions to conflicts

  • The council is made up of the Prime Minister as chairman and the Chief Ministers of all states as members. The council has met 12 times since its inception.
  • However, some say the council lacks the technical and management experts and autonomy needed for effective functioning. Others say the council is less participatory and cooperative because civil society is not present or engaged.

The Union Ministry of Finance:

  • It implements the financial recommendations and manages the actual disbursement of funds, but it does not decide or recommend the principles of grants-in-aid.
  • It acts as the executive body that executes the financial arrangements approved by the Parliament or recommended by the Finance Commission. So, it only manages the money, not the principles of its distribution.

The Public Accounts Committee (PAC) :

  • It is a committee of members of parliament that audits the revenue and expenditure of the Government of India. The committee is constituted by the Parliament of India each year.
  • The PAC’s main function is to examine the audit report of the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) and submit its report to the parliament.
  • The committee also examines the value for money of public spending and holds the government and its civil servants accountable for the delivery of public services.
  • The PAC is made up of 22 members, 15 of whom are elected by the Lok Sabha and 7 of whom are appointed by the Rajya Sabha. Every member of Parliament elected in both the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha serves on the committee for a year.

question: Which one of the following amendments to the Indian Constitution empowers the President to send back any matter for reconsideration by the Council of Ministers? (UPSC Prelims 2002)

option_2: 40th

option_4: 44th

EXPLANATION : (D)

  • The 44th Amendment to the Indian Constitution, passed in 1978, gives the President the power to send matters back to the Council of Ministers for reconsideration. This amendment also restored certain fundamental rights that were suspended during the Emergency period (1975-77).
  • The 44th Amendment states that the President can send advice back for reconsideration once. If the Council of Ministers sends the same advice again, the President must accept it. The 44th Amendment also protects individuals from the future tendency of the majority to grant rights.

The 39th Amendment of the Constitution of India :

  • It is also known as The Constitution (Thirty Ninth Amendment) Act, 1975, was enacted on August 10, 1975. The amendment was passed during the Emergency of 1975 1977.
  • The amendment made the election of the President, the Vice President, the Prime Minister, and the Speaker of the Lok Sabha beyond the scrutiny of the Indian courts.
  • It also granted the Prime Minister immunity from the electoral laws applicable prior to the amendment. The amendment was passed in response to the Allahabad High Court’s judgment which had quashed Mrs. Indira Gandhi’s election on grounds of electoral malpractice.
  • The Supreme Court declared the amendment unconstitutional in the Keshvananda Bharti Case and the Menaka Gandhi Case.

The 40th Amendment of the Indian Constitution :

  • It was enacted in 1976 and went into effect on May 27, 1976. The amendment gave Parliament the power to define India’s territorial seas, continental shelf, exclusive economic zone (EEZ), and maritime zones. It also amended article 297 of the Constitution to state that all lands, minerals, and other resources within the EEZ belong to the Union.
  • The 40th Amendment also included 64 additional central and state laws related to land reforms. These laws were part of the ninth schedule of the amendment. The 42nd Amendment of the Indian Constitution was passed in 1976 during a period of emergency in India.
  • The 42nd Amendment gave primacy to the Directive Principles, by stating that “no law implementing any of the Directive Principles could be declared unconstitutional on the grounds that it violated any of the Fundamental Rights”.

The amendment made several changes to the constitution, including:

1. Changing the description of India :

  • The amendment changed the description of India from a “sovereign democratic republic” to a “sovereign, socialist secular democratic republic”.

question: In the Indian Constitution, the Right to Equality is granted by Five Articles. They are.......... (UPSC Prelims 2002)
option_1: Article 16 to Article 20
option_2: Article 15 to Article 19
option_3: Article 14 to Article 18
option_4: Article 13 to Article 17
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (C)

  • The Right to Equality is granted by Articles 14 to 18 of the Indian Constitution. These articles guarantee the right to equality to every citizen of India.

The five articles are:

1. Article 14: Equality before the law

2. Article 15: Prohibition of discrimination

3. Article 16: Equality of opportunity in matters of public employment

4. Article 17: Abolition of untouchability

5. Article 18: Abolition of titles

  • Articles 14, 15, and 16 represent the general principles of equality before law and non discrimination. Articles 17 and 18 seek to further the cause of social equality.
  • The right to equality is a fundamental principle that ensures fairness and equal treatment for all. It means that every individual, regardless of their background, should be treated the same under the law.

question: The term of the Lok Sabha........... (UPSC Prelims 2002)
option_1: cannot be extended under any circumstances
option_2: can be extended by six months at a time
option_3: can be extended by one year at a time during the proclamation of emergency
option_4: can be extended for two years at a time during the proclamation of emergency
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (C)

  • The Lok Sabha usually operates for five years from the date of its first meeting. However, Parliament can extend this period by law or decree if a proclamation of emergency is in operation.
  • The 5th Lok Sabha (1971–1977) is an example of a Lok Sabha whose term was extended. The House’s term was extended twice by one year each time, but it was dissolved after five years, 10 months, and six days.

question: In the case of election to the Lok Sabha, the amount of Security deposited for general category candidates and SC/ST category candidates respectively is........... (UPSC Prelims 2002)
option_1: Rs 3,000 and Rs 2,500
option_2: Rs 10,000 and Rs 2,500
option_3: Rs 10,000 and Rs 5,000
option_4: Rs 15,000 and Rs 7,500
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (C) 

  • In India, every candidate who files a nomination for Lok Sabha or State Assembly elections is required to deposit a security amount with the Election Commission. This requirement is laid down in Section 34 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.
  • The purpose of this deposit is to discourage non-serious candidates from contesting elections merely for publicity or to clutter the ballot. The deposit is refunded if the candidate secures at least one-sixth (1/6th) of the total valid votes polled in the constituency; otherwise, it is forfeited to the government.

Current Amounts (as per the Representation of the People (Amendment) Act, 1996):

For Lok Sabha elections:

  • General category candidates: 10,000
  • SC/ST candidates: 5,000

For State Legislative Assembly elections:

  • General category candidates: 5,000
  • SC/ST candidates: 2,500

question: The 93rd Constitutional Amendment Bill deals with the.......... (UPSC Prelims 2002)
option_1: continuation of reservation for backward classes in government employment
option_2: free and compulsory education for all children between the age of 6 and 14 years
option_3: reservation of 30 per cent posts for women in government recruitments
option_4: allocation of more number of parliamentary seats for recently created States
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (B)

  • The 93rd Amendment Act of 2005 to the Indian Constitution added a clause to Article 15. This clause allows the government to make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes of citizens. This includes the scheduled castes and scheduled tribes.

The 93rd Amendment Act also:

1. Provides for the admission of backward classes in educational institutions

2. Makes free and compulsory education for children between the ages of 6 and 14, a fundamental right

3. Brings private colleges and unaided education institutions under the government’s reservation policy

  • The 93rd Amendment Act was passed by Parliament in 2006.

question: Under which article of the Indian Constitution did the President make reference to the Supreme Court to seek the Court’s opinion on the Constitutional validity of the Election Commission’s decision on deferring the Gujarat Assembly elections (in the year 2002)? (UPSC Prelims 2002)
option_1: Article 142
option_2: Article 143
option_3: Article 144
option_4: Article 145
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (B)

Article 143 of the Indian Constitution :

  • It gives the Supreme Court advisory jurisdiction. This means that the President can ask the Supreme Court for its opinion on any matter of public importance. The President can seek the Supreme Court’s opinion on any question of law or fact that has arisen or is likely to arise.
  • Article 142 of the Indian Constitution gives the Supreme Court the power to “do complete justice” between parties when the law does not provide a remedy. In these situations, the court can resolve a dispute in a way that fits the facts of the case.
  • Article 144 of the Indian Constitution requires all civil and judicial authorities in India to assist the Supreme Court. It states that civil and judicial authorities are subordinate to the Supreme Court’s power to carry out its orders and decisions.

Article 145 of the Indian Constitution gives the Supreme Court the power to make rules and laws regarding the following matters:

1. Persons appointed to the Supreme Court

2. Procedure for appeals

3. Cost of proceedings

4. Bail

5. Court proceedings regarding the transfer of cases

6. Stay of proceedings.

question: Which one of the following High Courts has the Territorial Jurisdiction over Andaman and Nicobar Islands? (UPSC Prelims 2003)
option_1: Andhra Pradesh
option_2: Calcutta
option_3: Madras
option_4: Orissa
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (B)

  • The Calcutta High Court has jurisdiction over the Andaman and Nicobar Islands. The Calcutta High Court is India’s oldest high court, established in 1862. It also has jurisdiction over the state of West Bengal. The Indian Constitution’s Articles 214–231 cover the High Courts, their organization, and powers.
  • India has 25 High Courts. These courts are the highest courts in their respective states and union territories. They have jurisdiction over all civil and criminal matters within their jurisdiction. The oldest High Courts in India are Bombay, Madras, and Kolkata, established in 1862. The newest High Courts are Andhra Pradesh and Telangana, established in 2019.
  • Three High Courts have jurisdiction over more than one state. The Union Territories of Delhi, Jammu & Kashmir, and Ladakh have their own High Courts. The other five Union Territories come under the jurisdiction of different State High Courts.

Here are some high courts in India and the states they cover:

1. Kerala High Court: The highest court for the state of Kerala, and also decides cases from the Union Territory of Lakshadweep.

2. Madras High Court: The high court of the Indian state of Tamil Nadu.

3. Punjab and Haryana High Court: A common institution that caters to both these states.

4. Bombay High Court: Has jurisdiction over the Indian states of Maharashtra, Goa, and the Union Territories of Daman and Diu and Dadra and Nagar Haveli.

5. Karnataka High Court: The highest court of judicature in the state.

6. Chhattisgarh High Court: Has jurisdiction over the state of Chhattisgarh.

7. Kolkata High Court : The court’s jurisdiction covers the state of West Bengal and the Union Territory of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

8. Guwahati High Court : Has jurisdiction over the following states: Assam, Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland, Mizoram.

question:
Consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2003)

1 The joint sitting of the two houses of the Parliament in India is sanctioned under Article 108 of the Constitution

2. The first joint sitting of Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha was held in the year 1961

3. The second joint sitting of the two Houses of Indian Parliament was held to pass the Banking Service Commission (Repeal) Bill

Which of these statements is/are correct?
option_1: 1 and 2
option_2: 2 and 3
option_3: 1 and 3
option_4: 1, 2 and 3
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (D)

  • A joint sitting of Parliament is a constitutional provision that resolves a deadlock between the two Houses of Parliament over Ordinary or Finance bill. Joint sittings cannot be held for money bills or constitutional amendment bills.
  • The President of India can call a joint sitting of Parliament, and the Speaker of the Parliament presides over it.
  • The first joint sitting of the Indian Parliament was held on May 18, 1961 to consider the Dowry Prohibition Bill.
  • The joint sitting was called because there was a disagreement between the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha over some amendments to the bill.

A joint session can be summoned when:

1. One House passes a bill and transmits it to the other House

2. The other House rejects the bill

3. An ordinary bill has been rejected by any house of the parliament and if more than six months have elapsed

  • The bill is passed by a simple majority of a joint sitting.

As of July 31, 2023, a joint session has been called only three times:

1. Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961

2. Banking Service Commission Act (Repeal), 1978

3. Prevention of Terrorism Act, 2002

question: The Ninth Schedule to the Indian Constitution was added by........... (UPSC Prelims 2003)
option_1: First Amendment
option_2: Eighth Amendment
option_3: Ninth Amendment
option_4: Forty second Amendment
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (A)

  • The Ninth Schedule of the Indian Constitution was added by the Constitution (First Amendment) Act, 1951. The schedule lists central and state laws that cannot be challenged in courts. The first amendment added 13 laws to the schedule.
  • The Eighth Amendment of the Indian Constitution was passed in 1959. It extended the reservation period for Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and Anglo-Indians in the Lok Sabha and State Legislative Assemblies.
  • The Ninth Amendment Act of 1960 made it legal for India to transfer disputed territories to Pakistan. The amendment was a result of agreements between India and Pakistan in 1958, 1959, and 1960.
  • The amendment allowed for the transfer of territory in Berubari, West Bengal to Pakistan. The amendment also helped with minor territory adjustments as a result of the India-Pakistan agreement.

question: Which one of the following Articles of the Indian Constitution provides that ‘It shall be the duty of the Union to protect every State against external agression and internal disturbance? (UPSC Prelims 2003)
option_1: Article 215
option_2: Article 275
option_3: Article 325
option_4: Article 355
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (D)

  • Article 355 of the Indian Constitution states that it is the Union’s duty to protect every state from internal disturbance and external aggression. The article also states that the Union must ensure that the government of each state is carried out in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution.
  • Article 355 also allows the extension of the Union’s executive powers in any state. It also states that the powers of the state legislature can be exercised by or under the authority of the parliament.
  • Article 325 of the Indian Constitution states that no one can be excluded from a special electoral roster based on caste, race, religion, or sex. This means that everyone is eligible for inclusion in a special electoral roll for any constituency.
  • Article 275 of the Constitution of India provides grants-in-aid to states that Parliament determines are in need of assistance. The grants are paid out of the Consolidated Fund of India each year, and different sums may be fixed for different states. The primary purpose of Article 275 is to promote the welfare of the Scheduled Tribes in that State or raise the administration level of the Scheduled Areas.
  • Article 215 of the Constitution of India states that every High Court is a court of record. This means that High Courts have the power to correct records, including reviewing their own judgments and orders. This power also includes correcting errors that are apparent on the face of the records.

question: Under which Article of the Indian Constitution did the President give his assent to the ordinance on electoral reforms when it was sent back to him by the Union Cabinet without making any changes (in the year 2002)? (UPSC Prelims 2003)
option_1: Article 121
option_2: Article 122
option_3: Article 123
option_4: Article 124
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (C)

  • The President of India gave his assent to the ordinance on electoral reforms in 2002 under Article 123 of the Constitution of India.
  • Article 123 gives the President the power to issue ordinances when one or both houses of Parliament are not in session. Ordinances are laws that have the same effect as an Act of Parliament. They allow the government to take immediate legislative action.
  • Ordinances cease to operate if Parliament does not approve them within six weeks of reassembly, or if both Houses pass disapproving resolutions.
  • Article 121 of the Indian Constitution restricts parliamentary discussion. It states that Parliament cannot discuss the conduct of a Supreme Court or High Court judge while performing their duties. Discussion is only permitted if a motion is made to ask the President to remove the judge.
  • Article 122 of the Constitution of India restricts courts from inquiring into Parliament proceedings. It also states that the validity of any proceedings in Parliament cannot be questioned on the basis of any alleged procedural irregularity.
  • Article 124 of the Indian Constitution establishes and defines the Supreme Court of India. The Supreme Court is the highest judicial body in the country.

question: Which one of the following Bills must be passed by each House of the Indian Parliament separately, by special majority? (UPSC Prelims 2003)
option_1: Ordinary Bill
option_2: Money Bill
option_3: Finance Bill
option_4: Constitution Amendment Bill
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (D)

  • The Constitution Amendment Bill is the only bill that must be passed by each House of the Indian Parliament separately, by aspecial majority.

Special majorities in the Indian Parliament include:

1. Special majority according to Article 249

2. Special majority according to Article 368

3. Special majority according to Article 368 + 50 percent state ratification by a simple majority

  • An ordinary bill is a draft legislation that can be introduced in either house of the Indian Parliament. It can be introduced by a minister or a private member. The bill must pass through both houses of parliament, and the upper house has the authority to change or neglect the bill.
  • According to Articles 107 and 108 of the Indian Constitution, an ordinary bill is concerned with any issue other than financial matters. It covers matters excluded in money bills such as finance bill, constitution amendment bills, etc.
  • To pass an ordinary bill, a simple majority of members present and voting is required. However, to pass a bill to amend the Constitution, a majority of the total membership of the House and a majority of not less than two-thirds of the members present and voting is required in each House of Parliament.
  • The Finance Bill forms a part of the Union Budget, with details about all the legal amendments required for the changes in taxation proposed by the Finance Minister of the country. Money bills are concerned with financial matters like taxation, public expenditure, etc.

question: Which of the following Constitutional Amendments are related to raising the number of Members of Lok Sabha to be elected from the States? (UPSC Prelims 2003)
option_1: 6th and 22nd
option_2: 13th and 38th
option_3: 7th and 31st
option_4: 11th and 42nd
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (C)

The 7th and 31st Constitutional Amendments are related to raising the number of Members of Lok Sabha to be elected from the States:

1. 7th Amendment :

  • Provides for an elected representation of Lok Sabha seats from states and re adjustment after every census. This amendment was passed in 1956.

2. 31st Amendment :

  • Increases the upper limit for the representation of states in the Lok Sabha from 500 to 525 and reduces the upper limit for the representation of UTS from 25 to 20. This amendment was passed in 1973.
  • The 31st Amendment’s purpose was to increase the representation of states in the Lok Sabha. The main reason behind this amendment was the population of India revealed in the Census of 1971.

question:

1. to allow the withdrawal of money out of the Consolidated Fund of India.

2. to allocate between the States the shares of proceeds of taxes.

3. to consider applications for grants in aid from States.

4. to supervise and report on whether the Union and State governments are levying taxes in accordance with the budgetary provisions.

Which of these statements is/are correct?
option_1: Only 1
option_2: 2 and 3
option_3: 3 and 4
option_4: 1, 2 and 4

  • The commission makes recommendations to the president with regard to the distribution of the proceeds of taxes between the union and the states.
  • The principle which should govern the grants-in-aid to be given to the states. Any other matter referred to the Commission by the President in the interest of sound finance.

question:
Consider the following statements: In the Electoral College for Presidential Election in India........ (UPSC Prelims 2003)

1. the value of the vote of an elected Member of Legislative Assembly equals State Population Number of elected MLAs of the State x 100

2. the value of the vote of an elected Member of Parliament equals Total value of the votes of all elected MLAs Total number of elected MP’s

3. there were more than 5000 members in the latest election.

Which of these statements is/are correct?
option_1: 1 and 2
option_2: Only 2
option_3: 1 and 3
option_4: Only 3
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (B)

Statement 1 is incorrect.

  • The value of the vote of an elected Member of Legislative Assembly (MLA) in the electoral college for the Presidential Election in India is not determined by the state’s population divided by the number of elected MLAs.
  • The value of the vote of an MLA is determinedby the formula: Total Value of MLAs’ Votes = State Population / (Number of Elected MLAs of the state X 1000). The population of the state is divided by the total number of elected MLAs in the state multiplied by 1000, not 100.

Statement 2 is correct.

  • The value of the vote of an elected Member of Parliament (MP) in the electoral college for the Presidential Election is determined by dividing the total value of the votes of the elected MLAs by the total number of elected MPs. This ensures that each MP’s vote carries equal weight in the election.

Statement 3 is incorrect.

  • In the most recent Presidential elections (like 2022), the total members of the Electoral College were: 776 MPs (543 Lok Sabha + 233 Rajya Sabha), and 4,033 MLAs, making a total of 4,809 members. Even in earlier elections, the total has always been below 5000, so this statement is factually wrong.

question: The power to enlarge the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of India with respect to any matter included in the Union List of Legislative Powers rests with............ (UPSC Prelims 2003)
option_1: The President of India
option_2: The Chief Justice of India
option_3: The Parliament
option_4: The Union Ministry of Law, Justice and Company Affairs
solution_text:

  • According to Article 138 of the Constitution of India, the Parliament can enlarge the jurisdiction and power of the Supreme Court on any matter in the Union List.

The Parliament can also:

2. Organize jurisdiction

3. Modify the power of the Supreme Court

4. Increase or decrease the number of judges in the Supreme Court

5. Confer on the Supreme Court any further powers to entertain and hear appeals from any judgement,final order or sentence in a criminal proceeding of a High Court

question: Which one of the following statements is correct? (UPSC Prelims 2003)
option_1: Only the Rajya Sabha and not the Lok Sabha can have nominated members
option_2: There is a constitutional provision for nominating two members belonging to the Anglo Indian community to the Rajya Sabha
option_3: There is no constitutional bar for a nominated member to be appointed as a Union minister.
option_4: A nominated member can vote both in the Presidential and Vice Presidential elections
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (C)

  • Option A is wrong, Both houses Rajya Sabha (12) and Lok Sabha (2) members are nominated. Anglo Indian are nominated to Lok Sabha and not to RajyaSabha.
  • So option B is wrong, Nominated members enjoy all powers, privileges and immunities available to an elected member of Parliament. They take part in the proceedings of the House as any other member.
  • They, however, are not entitled to vote in the election of the President of India. But in the election of the Vice President of India, they have a right to vote. So far, none from them has been inducted into the Council of Ministers.
